Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Proposal to Investigate Coating and Substrate Thermal Noise for Advanced and Next Generation Gravitational Wave Detectors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The detection of gravitational waves on 14 September 2015 was an historic milestone in physics and astronomy. The detection was an important validation for General Relativity in both its confirmation of the existence of gravitational waves and in the accuracy of the predicted waveforms. The event was also a breakthrough in astronomy with the first direct detection of a black hole binary system. The era of gravitational wave astronomy has begun and with it comes increased expectations for more observations at greater sensitivity. The main obstacle to improved sensitivity is thermal noise in LIGO's mirror coatings. LIGO senses gravitational waves using an interferometer, an L-shaped detector with 4 km long arms. Identical light waves are sent from the vertex down orthogonal arms to a mirror. When the reflected beams recombine at the vertex the difference in phase corresponds to the arm length difference that can arise, in part, from gravitational waves. Thus the detection of gravitational waves depends on the precision detection of the surface of the end mirrors. LIGO operates at room temperature or 300; above absolute zero. Therefore the mirrors are relatively hot. That thermal energy is expressed as vibrations at the mirror's resonant frequencies. Those frequencies are much higher than the frequencies at which LIGO is designed to detect gravitational waves. If the mirrors were composed of ideal elastic materials, these vibrations would be ignored and of no concern. Indeed the special glass used for the mirror substrates is a nearly ideal elastic material. However the highly reflective mirror coating applied to the substrate has enough internal friction that it shifts some of the mirror's vibrational energy down to gravitational wave frequencies. That motion masks the gravitational wave signal and is termed mirror coating thermal noise. The goal of this research project is to produce a mirror coating with suffi;ciently reduced thermal noise in order to enable a significant increase in LIGO's sensitivity.

This award supports research to reduce coating thermal noise by lowering the dissipation, or mechanical loss, in the coating materials. This dissipation occurs when an oscillation in strain causes a state transition, such as a bond angle rotation, that emits a photon or phonon at de-excitation. This two state model is known as an asymmetric double-well potential. The dissipation is reduced by increasing the energy asymmetry in the states and thus lowering the transition probability. Annealing lowers dissipation by allowing the material to relax into its lowest energy state. It also reduces density fluctuations thereby raising the transition energy. But annealing is limited by low crystallization temperatures. Amorphous coatings are mixtures of high-index metal-oxide dielectrics in which the crystallization temperature is shifted above the effective annealing temperature. Recent advanced in work on amorphous silicon coatings show that the benefits of annealing can be obtained by depositing the coating on a heated substrate. Because the coating surface molecules are less constrained, the substrate temperatures are much less than the bulk annealing temperatures. The group will test this process in amorphous metal-oxide coatings and will investigate whether ion-assisted beam deposition might provide suffi;cient energy to the surface layer to effectively anneal the coating without any heating process. Finally, the group will continue work with Stanford's researchers on conductive coatings to combat charging noise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development of gravitational wave astronomy has opened a new and exciting window on the universe. Starting with the first direct detection of gravitational waves, LIGO has measured the inspiral and coalescence of dozens of binary black hole systems. This catalogue of events has allowed us to define the range of stellar mass black hole systems, an observation that would have been impossible using electromagnetic telescopes. LIGO has also been able to detected the inspiral of binary neutron star systems. When the neutron stars coalescence, an event known as a kilonova, there is a high rate of nucleosynthesis of the elements heavier than iron. 

These observations, made by the LIGO and Virgo Collaborations, have continued to expand and define the catalogue of black hole and neutron star binary systems. Yet, as the detections grow more numerous and the analysis techniques become more standardized, there is a growing scientific imperative to increase the detection rate. LIGO's instrument scientists believe that they can increase the detector sensitivity in order to see events at twice the distance of the current range. That detector upgrade, known as "A+", would increase the rate of events by 8x. The NSF has awarded funding for the A+ upgrade, which will employ quantum squeezing and reduced coating thermal noise. 

LIGO detects gravitational wave using an interferometer which senses the oscillating differential stretching and contracting in the length of its two orthogonal 4-km arms. The arm length is measured by reflecting light from mirrors suspended at the end of each arm. Coating thermal noise arises from the collective motion of the molecules in the room-temperature (300 K) mirror coatings. Mirror surface motion along the direction of the beam is indistinguishable, in the interferometer signal, to the motion of the entire mirror. In this way the thermal energy in the mirror coating generates noise in the detector. Coating thermal noise the the leading source of noise in the central region of LIGO's sensitivity. 

This grant award funds research to understand and reduce coating thermal noise for both the A+ upgrade and for the planned third generation detectors. The reduced coating thermal noise is achieved, primarily, by lowering the mechanical (or elastic) loss of the materials. While the coating materials maintain the same level of thermal energy, as the elastic loss is reduced, the collective motion of the mirror surface becomes increasingly well-defined and can be better filtered from the interferometer signal. The PI's research is conducted as part of the collaborative efforts of the LIGO Scientific Collaboration's Optics Working Group and Center for Coatings Research. 

The PI works on three research efforts to develop low elastic loss coatings: 

1)  AlGaAs Crystalline Coatings, 
2)  Stabilized, High-temperature Annealed, Amorphous Coatings, and 
3)  Heated Substrate Coatings. 

The PI participates in the coating design, and measures the mechanical loss, typically as a function of annealing temperature and frequency. 

There have been two major advances in this work during this grant cycle: 

1)  Using coatings designed and measured by the PI, a structural analysis was conducted using EXAFS measurements at SSRL. These measurements indicated that for amorphous tetrahedral glasses, the elastic loss is correlated with the type of intermolecular bond. Specifically, corner-shared bonds have the lowest loss at room temperature. Edge sharing shows higher loss, and face-sharing is the most lossy. This improved understanding is the basis of new investigations of potential low loss materials. 


2)  AlGaAs coatings, which experience thermoelastic and thermorefractive noise, can be thermo-optically optimized wherein the layer thicknesses are adjusts in order to cancel the thermoelastic and thermorefractive noise. These TO-optimized AlGaAs coatings have demonstrated very low elastic loss, well below the requirements for A+. These coatings also meet the A+ requirements for low optical loss. The remaining challenge is in producing AlGaAs coatings at the scale of LIGO mirrors. 

The broader impacts of this research extend most immediately to the precision physics community that can utilize LIGO's advanced research in noise reduction to better determine the physical parameters and principles that govern our universe. More broadly, the reduced coating thermal noise resulting from this research will lead to improved sensitivity of gravitational wave detectors, which will lead to an improved understanding of our universe.
